oracle.iam.access.realm

Class ServerAuthenticationModule

  • java.lang.Object
    • oracle.iam.access.realm.ServerAuthenticationModule
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    javax.security.auth.message.module.ServerAuthModule, javax.security.auth.message.ServerAuth

    public class ServerAuthenticationModule
extends java.lang.Object
implements javax.security.auth.message.module.ServerAuthModule
    The ServerAuthenticationModule validates client requests and secures responses to the client.

    The implementation assumes that may be used to secure different requests as different clients. It's also assumed that it may be used concurrently by multiple callers. For that purpose the module save and restore any state properly as necessary.

    Since:
    1.0.0.0
    Version:
    1.0.0.0

      • initialize

        public final void initialize(javax.security.auth.message.MessagePolicy request,
                             javax.security.auth.message.MessagePolicy response,
                             javax.security.auth.callback.CallbackHandler handler,
                             java.util.Map option)
                      throws javax.security.auth.message.AuthException
        Initialize this module with request and response message policies to enforce, a CallbackHandler, and any module-specific configuration properties.

        The request policy and the response policy must not both be null.

        Specified by:
        initialize in interface javax.security.auth.message.module.ServerAuthModule
        Parameters:
        request - the request policy this module must enforce, or null.
        Allowed object is MessagePolicy.
        response - the response policy this module must enforce, or null.
        Allowed object is MessagePolicy.
        handler - the CallbackHandler used to request information.
        Allowed object is CallbackHandler.
        option - the key-value pairs of module-specific configuration properties.
        Allowed object is Map.
        Throws:
        javax.security.auth.message.AuthException - if module initialization fails, including for the case where the options argument contains elements that are not supported by the module.

      • secureResponse

        public javax.security.auth.message.AuthStatus secureResponse(javax.security.auth.message.MessageInfo message,
                                                             javax.security.auth.Subject recipient)
                                                      throws javax.security.auth.message.AuthException
        Secure a service response before sending it to the client.
        This method is called to transform the response message acquired by calling getResponseMessage (on message) into the mechanism-specific form to be sent by the runtime.
        This method conveys the outcome of its message processing either by returning an AuthStatus value or by throwing an AuthException.
        Specified by:
        secureResponse in interface javax.security.auth.message.ServerAuth
        Parameters:
        message - a contextual object that encapsulates the client request and server response objects, and that may be used to save state across a sequence of calls made to the methods of this interface for the purpose of completing a secure message exchange.
        Allowed object is MessageInfo.
        recipient - a Subject that represents the source of the service response, or null. It may be used by the method implementation to retrieve Principals and credentials necessary to secure the response. If the Subject is not null, the method implementation may add additional Principals or credentials (pertaining to the source of the service response) to the Subject.
        Allowed object is Subject.
        Returns:
        An AuthStatus object representing the completion status of the processing performed by the method. The AuthStatus values that may be returned by this method are defined as follows:
        • AuthStatus.SUCCESS
          The application request message was successfully validated. The validated request message is available by calling getRequestMessage on message.
        • AuthStatus.SEND_SUCCESS
          To indicate that validation/processing of the request message successfully produced the secured application response message (in message). The secured response message is available by calling getResponseMessage on message.
        • AuthStatus.SEND_CONTINUE
          To indicate that message validation is incomplete, and that a preliminary response was returned as the response message in messageInfo. When this status value is returned to challenge an application request message, the challenged request must be saved by the authentication module such that it can be recovered when the module's validateRequest message is called to process the request returned for the challenge.
        • AuthStatus.SEND_FAILURE To indicate that message validation failed and that an appropriate failure response message is available by calling getResponseMessage on message.
        Throws:
        javax.security.auth.message.AuthException - when the message processing failed without establishing a failure response message (in message).

      • cleanSubject

        public void cleanSubject(javax.security.auth.message.MessageInfo message,
                         javax.security.auth.Subject subject)
                  throws javax.security.auth.message.AuthException
        Remove method specific principals and credentials from the subject.

        Called in response to a HttpServletRequest.logout() call.

        Specified by:
        cleanSubject in interface javax.security.auth.message.ServerAuth
        Parameters:
        message - a contextual object that encapsulates the client request and server response objects, and that may be used to save state across a sequence of calls made to the methods of this interface for the purpose of completing a secure message exchange.
        Allowed object is MessageInfo.
        subject - the Subject instance from which the Principals and credentials are to be removed.
        Allowed object is Subject.
        Throws:
        javax.security.auth.message.AuthException

      • validateRequest

        public javax.security.auth.message.AuthStatus validateRequest(javax.security.auth.message.MessageInfo message,
                                                              javax.security.auth.Subject source,
                                                              javax.security.auth.Subject recipient)
                                                       throws javax.security.auth.message.AuthException
        Authenticate a received service request.
        This method is called to transform the mechanism-specific request message acquired by calling getRequestMessage (on messageInfo) into the validated application message to be returned to the message processing runtime. If the received message is a (mechanism-specific) meta-message, the method implementation must attempt to transform the meta-message into a corresponding mechanism-specific response message, or to the validated application request message. The runtime will bind a validated application message into the the corresponding service invocation.

        This method conveys the outcome of its message processing either by returning an AuthStatus value or by throwing an AuthException.

        Specified by:
        validateRequest in interface javax.security.auth.message.ServerAuth
        Parameters:
        message - a contextual object that encapsulates the client request and server response objects, and that may be used to save state across a sequence of calls made to the methods of this interface for the purpose of completing a secure message exchange.
        Allowed object is MessageInfo.
        source - a Subject that represents the source of the service request. It is used by the method implementation to store Principals and credentials validated in the request.
        Allowed object is Subject.
        recipient - a Subject that represents the recipient of the service request, or null.
        It may be used by the method implementation as the source of Principals or credentials to be used to validate the request.
        If the Subject is not null, the method implementation may add additional Principals or credentials (pertaining to the recipient of the service request) to the @link Subject}.
        Allowed object is Subject.
        Throws:
        javax.security.auth.message.AuthException
